It is with deep sorrow that Addis Ababa University (AAU) mourns the passing of Professor Tenalem Ayenew, a distinguished scholar, mentor, and colleague.

Prof. Tenalem was a senior and renowned hydrologist and hydrogeologist whose lifelong dedication to water resources exploration, design, supervision, and management has left an enduring impact on Ethiopia and across Africa. With a Ph.D. in Hydrogeology from the Free University of Amsterdam, and advanced degrees in groundwater surveying (ITC, Enschede) and hydrology (IHE, Delft), alongside a B.Sc. in Geology from Addis Ababa University, he exemplified academic excellence and professional commitment.

 We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, colleagues, students, and all who had the privilege of working with him. 

His Funeral will be held today at Arat Kilo Kidist Selassie Church at 3 pm 

May his soul rest in eternal peace.

It is with deep sorrow that we announce the passing of Dr. Mesfin Addisse Dersehe on August 25, 2025. A distinguished scholar, a towering figure in public health , and a man of profound humility, Dr. Mesfin leaves behind a legacy of service, scholarship, and compassion that has touched countless lives across Ethiopia and beyond.
His contributions to medicine, public health, and academic leadership were transformative, and his mentorship shaped generations of health professionals. As we mourn his loss, we also honor the enduring impact of his lifeâ€™s work and the values he embodied.
His funeral will be held today on August 25, 2025 at Arada Giorgis Church at 2:00 pm.
 Our condolences to his family, colleagues and students. May his memory continue to inspire us.

Subject: Announcement of Promotions to Full Professor Rank
Dear Members of the AAU Community,
We are pleased to share the congratulatory news that, during its meeting held on 29 July 2025, the Governing Board of Addis Ababa University approved the promotion of 14 esteemed staff members to the rank of Full Professor.
This milestone reflects our collective pursuit of academic excellence, and stands as a testament to the outstanding contributions of these faculty members across education, research, and community service.
As we celebrate their achievements, we extend our heartfelt congratulations and appreciation for their unwavering dedication and impact. We look forward to their continued leadership in shaping the future of Addis Ababa University and contributing meaningfully to national development.
Warm regards,

We are pleased to announce the opening of the 2025/2026 call for applications for evidence-based community engagement initiatives. A total of 24 proposals will be selected, each receiving an award of 100,000 Birr.
Priority will be given to collaborative engagements that draw upon research findings to address community needs.
The deadline for submission is August 10, 2025.
Please find attached further details regarding the application process. For any inquiries, kindly contact us at community.services@aau.edu.et.

Call for Applications: Graduate Admission Test (GAT) and Graduate Programs at Addis Ababa University

Addis Ababa University is pleased to announce the opening of applications for the Graduate Admission Test (GAT), followed by admissions to graduate programs for the first semester of the 2025/26 Academic Year (2018 E.C.). Interested candidates are encouraged to review the details and eligibility criteria outlined in the attached official document.
Prospective applicants are advised to complete the GAT registration and subsequent application process within the indicated timeline. Successful candidates will have the opportunity to pursue advanced study across a range of disciplines at one of Africa's premier institutions of higher learning.

Dear AAU Students,
In todayâ€™s fast-changing job market, academic knowledge must be supplemented by soft skills necessary for any work environment. To help you bridge the gap between education and industry, Addis Ababa University, in collaboration with The i-Capital Africa Institute, is launching the LEAD (Live, Enjoy, Achieve, Develop) Life Design Lab.
This program is designed to equip you with practical skills in digital tools, problem-solving, and career developmentâ€”preparing you for the realities of the workplace. Addis Ababa University warmly extends its heartfelt congratulations on the approval of the following new professorships by the Governing Board on Tuesday, November 25, 2025.

We celebrate the distinguished scholars who have attained this honor nd commend their dedication to teaching, research, and service. Their contributions will continue to inspire generations of students and strengthen AAUâ€™s legacy as a beacon of higher education in Africa.

It is with deep sorrow thatÂ the AddisÂ AbabaÂ UniversityÂ mourns the passing ofÂ **Dr. Legesse Wolde-Yohannes,**Â a former staff of Aklilu Lemma Institute of Pathobiology, currently the Aklilu Lemma Institute of Health Research, distinguished scholar, mentor, and colleague.
**Dr. Legesse Wolde-YohannesÂ **was a senior and renownedÂ horticultural scientistÂ and whose lifelong dedication to Endod research has left an enduring impact on bilharzia/schistosomiasis control in Ethiopia and across Africa.
**Dr. Legesse Wolde-YohannesÂ **carried out relevant agrobotanical studies and also developed manuals/procedures of extraction and application of Endod for schistosomiasis control.
For his prominent contribution on studies on Endod and the control ofÂ bilharzia/schistosomiasis,Â **Dr. Legesse Wolde-Yohannes**, together with Professor Aklilu Lemma received theÂ **Right Livelihood AwardÂ **(Alternative Nobel Prize) in 1989.
His passing is a profound loss to AAU, the scientific community, and the nation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, colleagues, students, and all who had the privilege of working with him. His legacy of scholarship, mentorship, and service will continue to inspire generations to come.
His Funeral will be held tomorrow, on Sunday,Â January 25, 2026 (17 Tir 2018 EC, sidist saâ€™at)Â Â  at Mekanisa Abo Church at 12 pm (noon).
**May his soul rest in eternal peace.**

It is with deep sorrow that Addis Ababa University (AAU) mourns the passing of Professor Tenalem Ayenew, a distinguished scholar, mentor, and colleague.

Prof. Tenalem was a senior and renowned hydrologist and hydrogeologist whose lifelong dedication to water resources exploration, design, supervision, and management has left an enduring impact on Ethiopia and across Africa. With a Ph.D. in Hydrogeology from the Free University of Amsterdam, and advanced degrees in groundwater surveying (ITC, Enschede) and hydrology (IHE, Delft), alongside a B.Sc. in Geology from Addis Ababa University, he exemplified academic excellence and professional commitment.

We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, colleagues, students, and all who had the privilege of working with him. 

His Funeral will be held today at Arat Kilo Kidist Selassie Church at 3 pm 

May his soul rest in eternal peace.

Subject: Urgent Request for Medical Support

Dear Addis Ababa University Students and the University Community,

We respectfully write this letter to draw your kind attention to an urgent humanitarian matter that requires compassion and collective support.

Prof. Sintayehu Alamirew, a former lecturer in Genetics and Plant Breeding at Jimma University, faithfully served the academic community for more than 32 years. His daughter, Yemariam Sintayehu, was a freshman student at Addis Ababa University in 2017 E.C.

Sadly, Yemariam is currently suffering from a severe mental health disorder, which has forced her to withdraw from her studies. She is undergoing intensive and long-term medical treatment, the cost of which is estimated at 10,000,000 ETB. The family has exhausted all available financial resources and properties and is no longer able to cover the treatment expenses.

In view of this critical situation, we humbly appeal to all students and compassionate individuals, in the name of God, to extend any possible medical or financial support to help save Yemariamâ€™s life.

Bank Details for Support:
Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE)
Account Number: 1000018352846

Your generosity, prayers, and solidarity will make a profound difference during this difficult time.

With sincere gratitude,

CVCTF Cyber Awareness Day | December 13

We successfully hosted CVCTF Cyber Awareness Day as an onsite cybersecurity event at College of Technology and Built Environment (CTBE), bringing students together for hands-on learning, problem-solving, and community building in cybersecurity.

The event featured Capture The Flag (CTF) challenges, welcoming both experienced participants and first-time CTF players, and concluded with an award and certificate ceremony recognizing:

> March 2025 CVCTF & Hackathon winners

> December 13 CVCTF challenge winners

Beyond competition, the program focused on cyber awareness, teamwork, and encouraging students to explore cybersecurity through practical experience.

We would like to sincerely thank and acknowledge:

> Menas Cyber Solutions for sponsoring and supporting the event

> Yekolo Temari for continuous support

> Geez Security  Nathan Hailu, Abdurezak Hamid, and Abogn Pictures for their contributions during the March 2025 CVCTF event

> College of Technology and Built Environment (CTBE) for hosting and supporting student-led initiatives

Events like this strengthen our mission at Cyber Vanguard-to build a skilled, aware, and collaborative cybersecurity community through hands-on learning.

More cybersecurity initiatives and CVCTF challenges are coming soon.
Stay connected.

â€¢ A brief summary (approx. 3 sentences) of your experience

â€¢ Admission to the center is restricted to confirmed invitees.

We look forward to celebrating your dedication and the power of volunteerism.

Important Announcement: Cost Sharing Update

Dear Students,
The Student Council has been closely monitoring the cost sharing process across all campuses. We are pleased to inform you that most colleges are now in the final stages of completing their cost sharing arrangements. They have committed to finalizing the process by Hidar 5. However, if any college completes its preparations earlier, disbursements may begin before that date.
    Payment Schedule:
â€¢  Freshman students will receive cost sharing for two months: Tikmt and Hidar.
â€¢  Second-year and above students will receive cost sharing for three months: Meskerem, Tikmt, and Hidar.
     Special Notice:
If a college currently lacks sufficient funds for this month:
â€¢  Senior students will be paid for two months.
â€¢  Freshman students will be paid for one month. The remaining balance will be disbursed next month.

Please note that Sefere Selam and Tikur Anbessa colleges are continuing their cost sharing payments as scheduled.

If you have any questions or concerns regarding the cost sharing process, feel free to reach out to the Student Council.

ğŸ“Š Career Path Game: Interactive board or card game exploring career options.

ğŸ¤ Open Mic Tips: Students share their best job-hunting hacks or experiences.

The program is built to spark curiosity, build confidence, and give students actionable insights they can use right away.

[Placement - 2018] - Update
(CTBE - Year II (2017 Entry) Students)

Here are some of the frequently asked questions (FAQs) received through our emails and office following the placement results.
Please note that questions already addressed during the orientation session will not be repeated here.


1. Can self-sponsored students change their initial department or placement secured during University Entrance?

Answer: No. This is not possible unless we receive an official notification from the Main Registrar. We will maintain the departments as officially reported to us.

2. I am a self-sponsored student who secured a department/placement during University Entrance, but my name is not included in the department list sent from the main Registrar. Can you verify and complete my placement?

Answer: We cannot verify or process such cases. The Main Registrar must send us official information for any placement action to be taken.


3. Is there any possibility of requesting a transfer?

Answer: At this time,** transfer requests**â€”either to leave CTBE or to change departments within CTBEâ€”are **not allowed.  A student should stay in the placed department at least one semester.**


4. I failed to fill out the preference form on time. What will happen?

Answer: Students who did not fill and submit the form on time will still be placed, how, refer the information communicated during the orientation session.

---

NB:
Most of these questions were already covered during the orientation session and are available in the slides and recorded video shared with you. Those who missed the session are advised to consult your classmates or review our previous posts.

Examination rules! â€“ MUST READ!**


**1. Permitted and forbidden items**

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ It is not allowed to bring mobile phones, smart watches, or any other electronic device (except scientific calculators) to exam hall. Any student caught during examination with mobile phones and smart watches either switched on or not, will be accounted for cheating. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Mobile phones shouldnâ€™t be used as substitute for calculators.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Students shouldnâ€™t wear hat and other type of clothes that hampers the invigilators inspection capacity.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Each student must bring his/her University ID card and keep on the chair visible to the invigilator. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿No student may be admitted into an examination hall 30 minutes after the beginning of the examination and no student may be allowed to leave an examination hall within 30 minutes of the beginning of an examination and before signing the examination attendance sheet.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿If a student is forced to leave an examination hall for health reasons, and in so far as the student is in a conscious and sound state of mind, the invigilator in attendance shall inform him of the fact that certification from a medical doctor must be obtained expeditiously to substantiate the claim of sickness or illness.

**2. Violation of examination regulations in an examination room **

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Copying from pieces of paper or any other source of information brought into an examination hall where such material is not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Working on or being found in possession of examination papers other than oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Exchanging information in the examination hall in oral, symbolic, written or any other means, such as mobile phones where these are not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Making use of someone elseâ€™s work, or parts thereof, without acknowledging the same and with deliberate intent to represent such material as oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Sitting for an examination in a module/course for which one has not been registered.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Taking an examination by proxy, i.e., through another party.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Disorderly conduct in an examination hall, including refusal to accept and abide by instructions given by the invigilator.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Being caught in the act of avoiding signing attendance sheets in an examination or trying to leave examination halls without submitting answer sheets in ways that could lead to claiming absence from the hall.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Engaging in any other act that is deemed inappropriate to the smooth and fair conduct of the examination.

**__Online Exam related__**

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿No student is allowed to take the scratch papers with him/her from the computer lab rooms. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Students must sign the portal out before they leave the computer.

**3. Penalty if a student commits an act of academic dishonesty **

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿He /she shall be suspended for a minimum of one academic year.

[Placement - 2018] - Update
(CTBE - Year II (2017 Entry) Students)

Here are some of the frequently asked questions (FAQs) received through our emails and office following the placement results.
Please note that questions already addressed during the orientation session will not be repeated here.


1. Can self-sponsored students change their initial department or placement secured during University Entrance?

Answer: No. This is not possible unless we receive an official notification from the Main Registrar. We will maintain the departments as officially reported to us.

2. I am a self-sponsored student who secured a department/placement during University Entrance, but my name is not included in the department list sent from the main Registrar. Can you verify and complete my placement?

Answer: We cannot verify or process such cases. The Main Registrar must send us official information for any placement action to be taken.


3. Is there any possibility of requesting a transfer?

Answer: At this time,** transfer requests**â€”either to leave CTBE or to change departments within CTBEâ€”are **not allowed.  A student should stay in the placed department at least one semester.**


4. I failed to fill out the preference form on time. What will happen?

Answer: Students who did not fill and submit the form on time will still be placed, how, refer the information communicated during the orientation session.

---

NB:
Most of these questions were already covered during the orientation session and are available in the slides and recorded video shared with you. Those who missed the session are advised to consult your classmates or review our previous posts.

The PECC/TLS Office

**Notice to Students on Program Placement Privileges**

Dear Students,

This is to inform applicants who wish to claim program placement privileges based on staff privilege, disability, or origin from less developed regions that you must submit the required evidence within the application deadline. Requests with incomplete documentation will not be considered.

**A. Spouse/Child of Full-Time Academic Staff (AAU)
**
As per Article 29.4 of the AAU Senate Legislation, spouses and children of full-time academic staff members who have served the University for at least three years are entitled to placement in the undergraduate program of their choice, provided they meet program requirements.
Applicants using this privilege must submit the following:

1. A letter from the HR Department of AAU confirming that the parent is a full-time academic staff member.

2. If the staff member is the mother, a birth certificate must be attached to verify the relationship.

3. A copy of the parentâ€™s AAU Staff ID card.

âš ï¸ Applications missing any of the above documents will not be processed.

**B. Applicants with Disabilities**

Students claiming placement privileges due to disability must submit official supporting documents verifying their condition.

**C. Applicants from Less Developed Regions**

The following regions are considered less developed:

Afar
Gambella
Somali
Harari
Benishangul Gumz

**Required evidences include:**

Proof of residence
Birth certificate
Grade 8 and Grade 12 certificates

__Additionally, verification will be conducted using the Registrar Officeâ€™s official records.__

â° Deadline: All supporting documents must be submitted by on Wednesday, September 24, 2025 at 4:00PM (Afternoon).

ğŸ“Œ Note: Our office will not take responsibility for late or incomplete submissions.

#Learn_at_AAU â€“ Notice to All Applicants
Undergraduate Admission (Regular & Extension Programs)
Academic Year 2025/26 (2018 E.C.)

Addis Ababa University is pleased to announce that applications are now open for admission to its Undergraduate Regular and Extension Programs for the 2025/26 Academic Year (2018 E.C.). Interested candidatesâ€”whether applying under government sponsorship (cost-sharing) or self-sponsorship, are invited to apply by fulfilling the requirements and procedures outlined below.

#Requirements for Self-Sponsored Applicants 

1. Applicants must have completed the Ethiopian Secondary School Leaving Certificate Examination (ESSLCE) administered by the Ministry of Education (MoE) and achieved passing marks, as required by the MoE, for the academic years 2014â€“2017 E.C.
2. Applicants must take the Undergraduate Admission Test (UAT) of Addis Ababa University and obtain the required minimum passing score of 50 percent.
3. Applicants with previous enrollment in other government universities (2015â€“2017 E.C.) must submit official proof of cost-sharing payments along with their academic credentials.
4. Applicants who pursued remedial education at any recognized institution must successfully pass the remedial qualifying examination.
5. Applicants must pass any additional assessments required by the University for specific programs, including health-related, law, and other fields of study.
6. If an applicantâ€™s ESSLCE and UAT results do not meet eligibility for their preferred program, they must consent to placement in an alternative field of study as determined by the University.

#Requirements for Government-Sponsored Applicants (Cost-Sharing Scheme) 

1. Applicants must have taken the 2017 E.C. ESSLCE and achieved the minimum cut-off score for higher education admission as determined by the Ministry of Education.
2. Applicants must take the UAT and obtain a minimum passing score of 50 percent.
3. Applicants must provide official proof of economic deprivation, obtained from their local administrative authority (Kebele/Woreda/Zone/District) or a recognized legal organization supporting their education.
4. Applicants must pass any additional assessments required by the University for health-related, law, and other specific fields of study.

#AAU Presidential Scholarship Requirements 

Applicants wishing to be considered for the AAU Presidential Scholarship must:

1. Achieve a minimum score of 500 in the 2017 E.C. ESSLCE.
2. Successfully pass the UAT administered by AAU.
3. Provide consent to be placed in a department alongside government-sponsored students, based on merit and institutional placement guidelines.

#Application Steps 

1. Open the AAU Admission Portal: [https://portal.aau.edu.et](https://portal.aau.edu.et)

2. Click Apply for Admission (left-hand side menu).

3. From the Undergraduate Student menu, select Apply.

4. Click Call for Undergraduate Regular Admission.

5. Click Apply Now after reviewing the programs.

6. Create an account using the Create Undergraduate Applicant Account form. Use a valid email address as your username and set your password.

7. Log in with your email and password to access your AAU application account.

8. Fill out the Personal Profile and Academic Profile forms, then click Update and Next.

9. Under Financing Your Study, select either:

   * Government Sponsorship: Upload supporting evidence for requesting sponsorship, then choose your freshman program (Natural Sciences or Social Sciences).
   * Self-Sponsorship: Select your top three program preferences, consent to placement conditions, and continue.

10. Upload the required documents:

* ESSLCE result certificate
* Remedial result certificate (if applicable)
* Grade 9â€“12 transcripts

11. Select your UAT Exam Location from the drop-down menu.
12. Read the Consent Statement, select Accept, and click Submit (review all information before submission).
13. Proceed to payment:

* Application fee: ETB 350
* UAT fee: ETB 750
* Total: ETB 1,100
* Payment via Telebirr (QR code scan or mobile number deduction). contiuned....

**2017 Placement for Pre-Engineering Students**
__(First Year Students - CTBE)__

The Academic Council of the College of Technology and Built Environment (CTBE) has made key decisions regarding pre-engineering placement periods and course rearrangements in its meeting held on April 28, 2025.

Following the merger of the former AAiT and EiABC into the CTBE, it has been decided that all Pre-Engineering students will now select their preferred program at the end of Year I, ensuring alignment with previous practices.

Further details, including course rearrangements, placement criteria and the orientation program schedule, will be communicated soon. Students will have the opportunity to **choose any of the 9 undergraduate programs within the CTBE**, with eligibility based on minimum cut-off points and entrance exam requirements, when applicable.

For any inquiries, please visit the Pre-Engineering and Common Courses office at NB Building (NB205B) or contact us via email: tls.ctbe@aau.edu.et.

**Academic Preference Instructions and Schedule
For the 2017 E.C. First-Year Students!**

```#Instructions for Submitting Preferences```
To submit your academic preferences, follow these steps:
Log in to portal.aau.edu.et and access your homepage.
You will find a list of disciplines available under each college and institute.
Rank your preferred disciplines/programs by assigning numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.) in the preference form.
Ensure you enter the correct number in front of each program.

#Important Notes:
Preferences must be submitted online via portal.aau.edu.et.
If you need assistance, visit the nearest registrarâ€™s office, where a clerk can help you submit your preferences. You must have a username and password to access the portal.
If you fail to submit your preferences before the deadline (February 25â€“26, 2025), the placement system will automatically assign you to a program without considering your choices.
Students interested in Medicine, Dental Medicine, and Pharmacy are expected to sit for entrance exam.
Available Colleges/Schools/Departments
A. Choices for Natural Science Students
Dental MedicineÂ (Entrance exam required)
MedicineÂ (Entrance exam required)
PharmacyÂ (Entrance exam required)
Veterinary Medicine
Veterinary Laboratory Technology
Other Health Sciences
Pre-Engineering in the College of Engineering and Built EnvironmentÂ (formerly AAIT)
Pre-Engineering in the Built EnvironmentÂ (formerly EiABC)
Computer Science
Information Systems
Other Natural Sciences
B. Choices for Social Science Students
LawÂ (Entrance exam required)
Other Social Sciences

#February 25â€“26, 2025
Students submit their preferences online.

The number of students eligible for the entrance exam will be determined by the respective colleges.

#The registrar will screen eligible candidates among applicants who selected Medicine, Dental Medicine, or Pharmacy as their first choice, based on their academic results (EUEE score and First Semester GPA), to determine who may sit for the entrance exam.

#February 27, 2025
The list of candidates eligible for the entrance exam will be communicated to the college of health sciences.
February 28, 2025

The College of Health Sciences administers the entrance exam for MD, DDM and pharmacy applicants.
March 3â€“4, 2025

#Colleges of Health Sciences notify the registrar of students who passed the selection criteria:
EUEE (35%) + First Semester GPA (35%) + Entrance Exam (30%)
Successful candidates are placed in the Schools of Medicine and Pharmacy.

#Candidates who do not pass the entrance exam will be reassigned based on their results and preferences:

EUEE (50%) + First Semester GPA (50%)
March 5, 2025
The registrar places all remaining students based on:
EUEE (50%) + First Semester GPA (50%)
March 5-7, 2025

The Registrar will handle complaints regarding placements

#March 7, 2025
Second-semester registration begins.

#March 10, 2025
Second-semester classes commences.

#Self-Sponsored Studentsâ€™ placement

Self-sponsored students who have already secured placement in a program do not need to submit preferences.
Those students without assigned programs must complete the online preference form.

#Those temporarily assigned to the School of Medicine, Dental Medicine, Pharmacy and Law must take the entrance exam and get the passing marks to secure their placement.

#Additional Information
Gender-Based Affirmative Action:
20% of total seats in all programs are allocated to female students.
For the Colleges of Health Sciences (CHS) and Law & Governance Studies (CLGS), affirmative action applies both before and after the entrance exam.

#Disability and Disadvantaged Regions Affirmative Action:
Applies to all programs except Medicine and Dental Medicine.
Cases of Inter-departmental transfer
There will not be inter-departmental transfer for this semseter.Â  Transfer will be effected on the second year, which will be on 2025/26 academic year.

**Noticeâ—ï¸**
 
For those who do not live in Addis Ababa, you must bring your TIN number with you when you come to the university. This is important because you cannot return to your area whenever you want due to the distance. To avoid being disturbed in the middle of your classes, it is essential to have your TIN number.

For those who live in Addis Ababa and are non-cafÃ© users, having a TIN number is especially important. If you do not have it, you will not receive the monthly cost-sharing amount (3,000 birr). Therefore, obtaining your TIN number is necessary.

For those who live in Addis Ababa and are cafÃ© users, having a TIN number is not mandatory However, it is still advisable to obtain it as soon as possible. If you are in class and do not have your TIN number, it could put you in a difficult situation.

Examination rules! â€“ MUST READ!**


**1. Permitted and forbidden items**

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ It is not allowed to bring mobile phones, smart watches, or any other electronic device (except scientific calculators) to exam hall. Any student caught during examination with mobile phones and smart watches either switched on or not, will be accounted for cheating. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Mobile phones shouldnâ€™t be used as substitute for calculators.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Students shouldnâ€™t wear hat and other type of clothes that hampers the invigilators inspection capacity.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Each student must bring his/her University ID card and keep on the chair visible to the invigilator. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿No student may be admitted into an examination hall 30 minutes after the beginning of the examination and no student may be allowed to leave an examination hall within 30 minutes of the beginning of an examination and before signing the examination attendance sheet.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿If a student is forced to leave an examination hall for health reasons, and in so far as the student is in a conscious and sound state of mind, the invigilator in attendance shall inform him of the fact that certification from a medical doctor must be obtained expeditiously to substantiate the claim of sickness or illness.

**2. Violation of examination regulations in an examination room **

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Copying from pieces of paper or any other source of information brought into an examination hall where such material is not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Working on or being found in possession of examination papers other than oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Exchanging information in the examination hall in oral, symbolic, written or any other means, such as mobile phones where these are not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Making use of someone elseâ€™s work, or parts thereof, without acknowledging the same and with deliberate intent to represent such material as oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Sitting for an examination in a module/course for which one has not been registered.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Taking an examination by proxy, i.e., through another party.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Disorderly conduct in an examination hall, including refusal to accept and abide by instructions given by the invigilator.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Being caught in the act of avoiding signing attendance sheets in an examination or trying to leave examination halls without submitting answer sheets in ways that could lead to claiming absence from the hall.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Engaging in any other act that is deemed inappropriate to the smooth and fair conduct of the examination.

**__Online Exam related__**

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿No student is allowed to take the scratch papers with him/her from the computer lab rooms. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Students must sign the portal out before they leave the computer.

[Placement - 2018] - Update
(CTBE - Year II (2017 Entry) Students)

Here are some of the frequently asked questions (FAQs) received through our emails and office following the placement results.
Please note that questions already addressed during the orientation session will not be repeated here.


1. Can self-sponsored students change their initial department or placement secured during University Entrance?

Answer: No. This is not possible unless we receive an official notification from the Main Registrar. We will maintain the departments as officially reported to us.

2. I am a self-sponsored student who secured a department/placement during University Entrance, but my name is not included in the department list sent from the main Registrar. Can you verify and complete my placement?

Answer: We cannot verify or process such cases. The Main Registrar must send us official information for any placement action to be taken.


3. Is there any possibility of requesting a transfer?

Answer: At this time,** transfer requests**â€”either to leave CTBE or to change departments within CTBEâ€”are **not allowed.  A student should stay in the placed department at least one semester.**


4. I failed to fill out the preference form on time. What will happen?

Answer: Students who did not fill and submit the form on time will still be placed, how, refer the information communicated during the orientation session.

---

NB:
Most of these questions were already covered during the orientation session and are available in the slides and recorded video shared with you. Those who missed the session are advised to consult your classmates or review our previous posts.

**Notice to Students on Program Placement Privileges**

Dear Students,

This is to inform applicants who wish to claim program placement privileges based on staff privilege, disability, or origin from less developed regions that you must submit the required evidence within the application deadline. Requests with incomplete documentation will not be considered.

**A. Spouse/Child of Full-Time Academic Staff (AAU)
**
As per Article 29.4 of the AAU Senate Legislation, spouses and children of full-time academic staff members who have served the University for at least three years are entitled to placement in the undergraduate program of their choice, provided they meet program requirements.
Applicants using this privilege must submit the following:

1. A letter from the HR Department of AAU confirming that the parent is a full-time academic staff member.

2. If the staff member is the mother, a birth certificate must be attached to verify the relationship.

3. A copy of the parentâ€™s AAU Staff ID card.

âš ï¸ Applications missing any of the above documents will not be processed.

**B. Applicants with Disabilities**

Students claiming placement privileges due to disability must submit official supporting documents verifying their condition.

**C. Applicants from Less Developed Regions**

The following regions are considered less developed:

Afar
Gambella
Somali
Harari
Benishangul Gumz

**Required evidences include:**

Proof of residence
Birth certificate
Grade 8 and Grade 12 certificates

__Additionally, verification will be conducted using the Registrar Officeâ€™s official records.__

â° Deadline: All supporting documents must be submitted by on Wednesday, September 24, 2025 at 4:00PM (Afternoon).

**Examination rules! â€“ MUST READ!**


**1. Permitted and forbidden items**

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ It is not allowed to bring mobile phones, smart watches, or any other electronic device (except scientific calculators) to exam hall. Any student caught during examination with mobile phones and smart watches either switched on or not, will be accounted for cheating. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Mobile phones shouldnâ€™t be used as substitute for calculators.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Students shouldnâ€™t wear hat and other type of clothes that hampers the invigilators inspection capacity.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Each student must bring his/her University ID card and keep on the chair visible to the invigilator. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿No student may be admitted into an examination hall 30 minutes after the beginning of the examination and no student may be allowed to leave an examination hall within 30 minutes of the beginning of an examination and before signing the examination attendance sheet.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿If a student is forced to leave an examination hall for health reasons, and in so far as the student is in a conscious and sound state of mind, the invigilator in attendance shall inform him of the fact that certification from a medical doctor must be obtained expeditiously to substantiate the claim of sickness or illness.

**2. Violation of examination regulations in an examination room **

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Copying from pieces of paper or any other source of information brought into an examination hall where such material is not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Working on or being found in possession of examination papers other than oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Exchanging information in the examination hall in oral, symbolic, written or any other means, such as mobile phones where these are not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Making use of someone elseâ€™s work, or parts thereof, without acknowledging the same and with deliberate intent to represent such material as oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Sitting for an examination in a module/course for which one has not been registered.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Taking an examination by proxy, i.e., through another party.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Disorderly conduct in an examination hall, including refusal to accept and abide by instructions given by the invigilator.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Being caught in the act of avoiding signing attendance sheets in an examination or trying to leave examination halls without submitting answer sheets in ways that could lead to claiming absence from the hall.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Engaging in any other act that is deemed inappropriate to the smooth and fair conduct of the examination.

**__Online Exam related__**

Following Addis Ababa University's autonomy reform, a powerful new force in education, research, and innovation has emerged: the College of Technology and Built Environment (CTBE)! This dynamic college brings together the expertise of the former Addis Ababa Institute of Technology (#AAiT) and the Ethiopian Institute of Architecture, Building Construction, and City Development (#EiABC) to shape the future of engineering, technology, and the built environment in Ethiopia and beyond. 

Join the #CTBE community as we push boundaries, drive research, and foster industry collaborations. Follow, share, and engage with us on LinkedIn to stay connected with cutting-edge advancements and inspiring achievements.

**2017 Placement for Pre-Engineering Students**
__(First Year Students - CTBE)__

The Academic Council of the College of Technology and Built Environment (CTBE) has made key decisions regarding pre-engineering placement periods and course rearrangements in its meeting held on April 28, 2025.

Following the merger of the former AAiT and EiABC into the CTBE, it has been decided that all Pre-Engineering students will now select their preferred program at the end of Year I, ensuring alignment with previous practices.

Further details, including course rearrangements, placement criteria and the orientation program schedule, will be communicated soon. Students will have the opportunity to **choose any of the 9 undergraduate programs within the CTBE**, with eligibility based on minimum cut-off points and entrance exam requirements, when applicable.

For any inquiries, please visit the Pre-Engineering and Common Courses office at NB Building (NB205B) or contact us via email: tls.ctbe@aau.edu.et.

__(2017 entry students)__

Welcome to the second semester of the academic year!  

**Please note that Registration Date is Friday, March 07, 2025. ** 

To ensure a smooth registration process, please follow this guide which provides instructions on how to process your second-semester registration and registration locations for those who change campuses due to your placement.

1. Check your placement status on the portal.

6. Check your assigned section on the portal.

**Examination rules! â€“ MUST READ!**


**1. Permitted and forbidden items**

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ It is not allowed to bring mobile phones, smart watches, or any other electronic device (except scientific calculators) to exam hall. Any student caught during examination with mobile phones and smart watches either switched on or not, will be accounted for cheating. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Mobile phones shouldnâ€™t be used as substitute for calculators.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Students shouldnâ€™t wear hat and other type of clothes that hampers the invigilators inspection capacity.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Each student must bring his/her University ID card and keep on the chair visible to the invigilator. 

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿No student may be admitted into an examination hall 30 minutes after the beginning of the examination and no student may be allowed to leave an examination hall within 30 minutes of the beginning of an examination and before signing the examination attendance sheet.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿If a student is forced to leave an examination hall for health reasons, and in so far as the student is in a conscious and sound state of mind, the invigilator in attendance shall inform him of the fact that certification from a medical doctor must be obtained expeditiously to substantiate the claim of sickness or illness.

**2. Violation of examination regulations in an examination room **

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿ Copying from pieces of paper or any other source of information brought into an examination hall where such material is not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Working on or being found in possession of examination papers other than oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Exchanging information in the examination hall in oral, symbolic, written or any other means, such as mobile phones where these are not specifically permitted.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Making use of someone elseâ€™s work, or parts thereof, without acknowledging the same and with deliberate intent to represent such material as oneâ€™s own.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Sitting for an examination in a module/course for which one has not been registered.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Taking an examination by proxy, i.e., through another party.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Disorderly conduct in an examination hall, including refusal to accept and abide by instructions given by the invigilator.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Being caught in the act of avoiding signing attendance sheets in an examination or trying to leave examination halls without submitting answer sheets in ways that could lead to claiming absence from the hall.

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿Engaging in any other act that is deemed inappropriate to the smooth and fair conduct of the examination.

**3. Penalty if a student commits an act of academic dishonesty **

ğŸ‘†ğŸ¿He /she shall be suspended for a minimum of one academic year.

Please disseminate  this information to all students!.....Dear Dr. Getasew,

I hope this message finds you well.

Since 2019, the University of Michigan has been running the African Undergraduate Research Adventure (AURA) program. This initiative is designed to give undergraduate students early exposure to graduate-level research and inspire them toward a career in research. The program began in collaboration with the then Addis Ababa Institute of Technology (AAiT), with 10 Ethiopian students participating in its first year. Many of these students have since gone on to pursue MSc and PhD programs at leading universities.

In later years, the program briefly expanded to include students from the University of Rwanda. Unfortunately, the program was paused last year due to uncertainties with U.S. visa processing. However, Iâ€™m pleased to share that the program will resume this year with a focus on recruiting Ethiopian students from the following units:

School of Electrical and Computer Engineering

School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

School of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering

School of Information Technology & Engineering

Center for Biomedical Engineering

Department of Computer Science

I kindly request your support in sharing this opportunity with the relevant schools and centers so that interested 4th-year (3rd year in case of Computer Science) students may apply.

Application link: https://forms.gle/TyLAKeUFs6ESYnj87
Application deadline: January 22, 2026

Thank you for your continued support.

Warm regards,

To all regular undergraduate first-year students,
Submission of Updated Grade 12 Examination Results

The Ministry of Education has revised the Ethiopian Secondary School Leaving Certificate
Examination (ESSLCE) (Grade 12) results for some students in September 2025. As these results
are a key criterion for placement into academic programs at the end of the first semester, it is
necessary to update the records accordingly.
Therefore, the Addis Ababa University Office of the Registrar kindly requests all concerned
students to submit their updated Grade 12 examination results by completing the Google Form
available at the link below:
https://forms.gle/WwBC8cRXi3ss6TtE6
The final deadline for submission is January 5, 2026. Students are advised to ensure that all
required information is completed accurately and submitted on time.
Thank you for your cooperation.

Addis Ababa University

sales process directly into the insurance context adapted for insurance agents:Â  

1. Prospecting â€“ identifying potential clients such as individuals, families, or businesses who may need coverage (motor, property, life, liability, etc.). This often involves networking, referrals, and partnerships with banks or SACCOs.Â  

2. Qualifying â€“ assessing whether the prospect has insurable assets, the financial capacity to pay premiums, and the authority to make decisions. For example, checking if a business owner is the policy decision-maker or if a family has budget for life insurance.Â  

3. Presenting â€“ explaining insurance products in simple, relatable terms. Demonstrate how motor insurance protects against accidents, or how life insurance secures family stability. Tailor presentations to the clientâ€™s risks and priorities.Â  

4. Handling objections â€“ addressing common concerns like â€œinsurance is too expensive,â€ â€œclaims take too long,â€ or â€œI donâ€™t trust insurers.â€ Provide clear evidence of claim processes, customer testimonials, and regulatory compliance to build confidence.Â  

5. Closing â€“ guiding the client to sign the policy agreement, finalize premium payments, and issue the cover note. In insurance, closing often requires patience and reassurance, since clients are committing to long-term protection.Â  

6. Follow-up â€“ maintaining the relationship through renewal reminders, claims support, and periodic check-ins. This stage is critical in insurance: satisfied clients often bring referrals and cross-sell opportunities (e.g., a motor client later buying property or health insurance).

Cost Sharing Update November 18

As part of our continued follow-up on the cost sharing disbursement process, we are pleased to confirm that FBE students have successfully received their cost sharing payments.

However, several campuses are still experiencing delays. In response, the Student Council formally reported the issue to the Office of the Vice President, Dr. Abdurazak. He has assured us that he will personally follow up with the relevant campus administrations. We have verified that he has already contacted each campus to expedite the process.

Current Status 
â€¢ School of Commerce, 4 kilo & 5 Kilo Campus
Disbursements are expected to be finalized shortly.

We encourage students from campuses still pending disbursement to contact their respective deans and request swift action. The Student Council has been actively following this process for several months and will continue to explore additional options to accelerate resolution.

**About Cover Letter,Resume & CV(Curriculum Vitae) **
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

**âœ…1. What Is Cover Letter? **

âœ”ï¸A cover letter includes general details about a person like name, contact information, educational and professional qualification, work experience and career goal or what a person is looking for in terms of a job profile. A cover letter should not be confused with a resume as it does not include all the details of a resume. 

âœ”ï¸A cover letter is an introduction to yourself with regard to the job opening you are applying for. Cover letters are generally one page at most in length, divided into a header, introduction, body, and closing.

âœ”ï¸Cover letter typically includes your contact information, addresses the hiring Company/Organization, and is tailored to a specific job posting or company.

**âœ…2. What Is Difference Between a Resume and a CV (Curriculum Vitae) **

âœ”ï¸A resume is a one- to two-page document presenting key facts about your professional experience, educational background, and skills. A CV (Curriculum Vitae) is a longer document that details the whole course of your career. A resume is used for job search, and a CV for academic purposes.

âœ”ï¸CVs are commonly split into distinct sections: a professional profile, your skills, a summary of your career, and a section on your education and qualifications. Details are usually presented in snappy bullet points, led by powerful verbs, and bolstered with concrete statistics, to show off your skill set and talent.

Note: Now that you have a clear idea about what CVs and resumes are, letâ€™s look at a complete list of the differences between them:-

âœ”ï¸Length. Resumes are typically short and vary between one and two pages long at most. CVs, on the other hand, can be as long as necessary, and if you have a lot of experience, they can go for up to dozens of pages.

âœ”ï¸Detail. Resumes should only include the most relevant information about you, while CVs contain your entire career history.

âœ”ï¸Function. Resumes are more than enough for most job applications, while CVs are mainly used in academic settings. Whether youâ€™re applying for a Ph.D. or for a position as a professor at a university, an academic CV is what youâ€™re going to need.

âœ”ï¸Tailoring. Resumes should always be tailored to the specific job youâ€™re applying to, so a single job search can include dozens of resumes when youâ€™re applying to different companies. CVs are always the same, regardless of where you apply, although they get longer as you gain more experience and qualifications.

âœ”ï¸Focus. Resumes highlight your work experience, professional achievements, and most impressive skills, while CVs prioritize education, research experience, and publications.

âœ”ï¸References. Typically, you donâ€™t need to list references on a resume unless the employer specifically requests them. However, academics are encouraged to include professional references in their CVs.

Announcement for the Passionate Learners of Geez Language at Addis Ababa University.
Are you fascinated by ancient languages? Do you have a burning passion to delve into the depths of our rich heritage? If so, we have an exhilarating opportunity for you!

The Geez Club at Addis Ababa University is thrilled to announce a comprehensive learning program designed specifically for those who are eager to learn the Geez language with out any payment. This initiative aims not only to preserve but to revitalize our connection to one of the oldest languages known to mankind.
Whether you are a beginner or already have some knowledge of Geez, this program is tailored to accommodate all levels of proficiency. 

The class will be held every Thursday from 11:30 - 12:30.

Join us and be a part of this remarkable journey.We look forward to welcoming you into our community and exploring the depths of Geez language together!

2.Astudent who has CGPA of 3.0 and above

3. The one who has no disciplinary sanction or warnings

Greetings everyone, 

On February 17, 2025, the Center of African and Asian Studies and the Sustainable Development Solutions Network (SDSN) will proceed with opening the SDSN Africa Center hosted by the Addis Ababa University. We are greatly honored to invite all TCU members to attend this special event, which will take place in the Ras Mekonnen Hall of the University from 10:00 a.m. to 01:30 p.m.

The SDSN, led by Professor Jeffrey Sachs ( he will attend it) under the auspices of the United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, has championed the promotion of integrated development approaches to implementing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Paris Agreement worldwide. Anchored in Addis, the SDSN Africa Center will provide the opportunity to engage African leaders and galvanize support globally to accelerate the implementation of SDGs across the region and progress toward the African Union Agenda 2063. This event will introduce and share the vision of the SDSN Africa Center.

Schedule to take apart on this event.

Sincerely,

Subject: Urgent Request for Medical Support

Dear Addis Ababa University Students and the University Community,

We respectfully write this letter to draw your kind attention to an urgent humanitarian matter that requires compassion and collective support.

Prof. Sintayehu Alamirew, a former lecturer in Genetics and Plant Breeding at Jimma University, faithfully served the academic community for more than 32 years. His daughter, Yemariam Sintayehu, was a freshman student at Addis Ababa University in 2017 E.C.

Sadly, Yemariam is currently suffering from a severe mental health disorder, which has forced her to withdraw from her studies. She is undergoing intensive and long-term medical treatment, the cost of which is estimated at 10,000,000 ETB. The family has exhausted all available financial resources and properties and is no longer able to cover the treatment expenses.

In view of this critical situation, we humbly appeal to all students and compassionate individuals, in the name of God, to extend any possible medical or financial support to help save Yemariamâ€™s life.

Bank Details for Support:
Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE)
Account Number: 1000018352846

Your generosity, prayers, and solidarity will make a profound difference during this difficult time.

With sincere gratitude,

**How Your Phone Can Steal Your Dream Before You Even Enter the Department You Want**
I have been observing many students spending most of their time on their phones â€” scrolling endlessly, sitting around the campus day and night, doing nothing meaningful. The most common excuse I hear is:
â€œClasses havenâ€™t properly started yetâ€¦â€
â€œLetâ€™s have some fun firstâ€¦â€
â€œOur section hasnâ€™t begun lectures anywayâ€¦â€
But what many donâ€™t realize is that __habits are formed in silence.__ The way you spend your â€œfreeâ€ time today will shape how you handle your academic responsibilities tomorrow.
When you get used to scrolling, procrastinating, and sleeping 8+ hours a day, **you will carry that same habit even after classes start.** Then one day, reality will suddenly hit:
Youâ€™ll have multiple assignments, exams around the corner, group work waiting, and other commitments piling up. Instead of handling them confidently, youâ€™ll feel overwhelmed.
Worse, you may slowly drift away from your spiritual life as well , skipping prayers, fellowships, and religious responsibilities, justifying it with â€œIâ€™m busyâ€ when in reality, your __time was consumed by your phone long before you became busy.__
And by the time you wake up to the problem, it may already be affecting your grades. Instead of choosing your dream department confidently, you may end up asking:

**â€œWhich department will accept me with my dropped grade?â€**
Your phone is not the enemy â€” your **relationship with it** is.
**Take care of your time before your phone takes care of your future.
Protect your dream before distraction steals it quietly.
**

A valuable opportunity to pursue your postgraduate studies at Addis Ababa University

The Department of Public Administration and Development Management (PADM) at Addis Ababa University invites motivated individuals to apply for its graduate programs for the 2025/26 academic year (2018 E.C.)

Programs Offered:

 MA in Public Policy and Development Management (Regular and Extension)
 PhD in Public Management and Policy (Regular)

These programs are designed for individuals committed to public service, effective policy-making, and sustainable development. They aim to equip students with the analytical tools and practical skills needed to shape policy, lead public institutions, and contribute to national and global development goals.

Application steps:

1. Register for the AAU Graduate Admission Test (GAT)

    Registration: July 7 â€“ August 17, 2025
    Exam dates: August 18 â€“ 25, 2025
    Register: [https://portal.aau.edu.et](https://portal.aau.edu.et)
    
2. Apply for the graduate program through the same portal (https://portal.aau.edu.et)
    
    Upload required documents
    Submit hard copies to the AAU Registrar, Main Campus, Room 203

For more information, contact:
Email: [challa.amdissa@aau.edu.et](mailto:challa.amdissa@aau.edu.et) | [defferew.kebebe@aau.edu.et](mailto:defferew.kebebe@aau.edu.et)
Phone: +251 111 229 602 | 0910 081 200
Office: Eshetu Chole Building, Offices 507 and 407, CoBE, AAU
AAU GAT Brochure

**B. General steps for applying to the AAU Graduate Program**
1. Open the portal of Addis Ababa University https://portal.aau.edu.et
2. Click on the Apply for Admission link on the second bar on the left side
3. On the top bar, you will find the Graduate drop-down menu. You can click on the Programs button to view the Graduate programs and their brief description.
4. Alternatively, you can scroll down to the right bottom side entitled Graduate Study, and click Find out what programs we offer before the Apply button.
5. Once you have an overview of the disciplines and the programs listed, click on Apply.
6. Fill out the application form and pay, via Telebirr, ETB 500 for the application fee using the application number generated during the filling of the application form.
7. After completing your payment, you will need to return to the application form and complete your online application by uploading your educational document (PDF-converted,) cost-sharing document, and a signed and stamped form of sponsorship letter if sponsored by a government institution.
8. Ph.D. applicants need to upload credentials of all the previous trainings (BA/BSc and MA/M.Sc. Degree and student copy).
9. Ph.D. applicants may need to attach additional documents depending on the requirements of the department or the program.
10. MA/MSC applicants will need to upload their BA/BSc degree and student copy.
11. Government-sponsored applicants can get the sponsorship form from downloads section of the university website (https://www.aau.edu.et/documents/registrar/).
12. Once the online application is completed, you must submit all the hard copies of your academic and other credentials in person to the AAU Admission Office, located on the second floor of the Main Campus Registrar Building, Room No. 203.
**Notice**
1. We would like to inform you that you will not be able to complete the registration process unless you order an official transcript to be sent in hard copy to the Addis Ababa University Registrar, PO Box 1176.
2. Department-level entrance exam schedules and admission requirements for programs are available on the department notice board and on the university website (https://admission.aau.edu.et/GraduatePrograms ).
3. Make sure you fulfill the admission requirements of the specific program as indicated in the curriculum of the specific program (uploaded on the website of the university).
4. Applicants for health disciplines will need to attach a letter from the Ministry of Health or a university grade report for each semester upon completion of their degree.
5. We would like to inform you that programs will be opened based on the minimum intake capacity of the programs.
6. Applicants who have attended school abroad should bring Higher Education Equivalence Letter from ETA and meet all the requirements set by the University.
7. Applicants who pass the GAT are required to submit a copy of their certificate between July 28 and August 27, 2025, at the Admission Office, Room 203, 2nd floor, Main Campus Registrar Building.

A. The AAU Graduate Admission Test (GAT)
1. Applicants must first take the University Graduate Admission Test (GAT) and fulfill the minimum requirement to pass the exam.
2. Information regarding the GAT can be obtained from t.me/addisababauniversityofficial
3. The application period for the University GAT is from July 7 to August 17, 2025.
4. The GAT will be administered in three rounds:
ï‚· First round: July 21â€“25, 2025
ï‚· Second round: August 04â€“08, 2025
ï‚· Third round: August 18-22, 2025
5. Follow the steps listed below and get registered for the GATá¡
  a. Visit: https://portal.aau.edu.et
  b. Click on â€˜Online Examsâ€™
  c. Under â€˜Quick Linksâ€™, click â€˜Apply for GATâ€™
  d. Complete the Test Taker Registration Form
  e. Upload a passport-size photo
  f. Click â€˜Submitâ€™
  g. Copy the generated registration number
  h. Pay the GAT testing fee of 750 ETB via Tele Birr. â€¢ Foreign applicants must pay an equivalent of USD 50: first, register by paying 750 ETB, then pay the remaining balance to AAUâ€™s Commercial Bank of Ethiopia account No. 1000087392067. â€¢ Submit the payment receipt to the Testing Center Telegram Channel and present a copy to the exam hall supervisor.
  i. After payment, download and print your Admission Ticket, which is required for entry to the exam hall.
  j. Follow updates via the Telegram Channel: Testing Center-AAU

**Important Notes:**
1. The GAT will be administered electronically. General exam information is available on the Telegram channel.
2. Applicants must regularly check the Telegram channel for updates regarding the test date, time, and venue.
3. Applicants who fail to appear on the scheduled test date must re-register and repay the fee to take the test at a later date.
4. GAT results from the previous year (as of September 2024) remain valid for the current application cycle.

On August 22, 2025, we proudly marked the successful graduation of 121 exceptional high school students from the AddisCoder Summer Program, hosted at the College of Technology and Built Environment (CTBE), Addis Ababa University.

AddisCoder is a free, intensive 4-week residential training camp that introduces Ethiopiaâ€™s brightest high schoolers to algorithms and programming. Since its inception in 2011, the program has grown into a national beacon of opportunity, empowering youth through world-class instruction delivered by Computer Science professors, industry experts from institutions such as Google, Meta, and teaching assistants from Ethiopian and other international universities, lecturers, and software Engineers.
